user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtMem2HexFile:
```c
bool UtMem2HexFile(const void *Memory, const char *Filename, uint32 Length)
{
    FILE * fp;
    uint32 i;
    uint32 j;

    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "w")))
    {
        for (i = 0; i < Length; i += 16)
        {
            fprintf(fp, "   %06lX: ", (unsigned long)i);
            for (j = 0; j < 16; j++)
            {
                if ((i + j) < Length)
                    fprintf(fp, "%02X ", ((uint8 *)Memory)[i + j]);
                else
                    fprintf(fp, "   ");
            }
            fprintf(fp, " ");
            for (j = 0; j < 16; j++)
            {
                if ((i + j) < Length)
                    fprintf(fp, "%c", isprint(((uint8 *)Memory)[i + j]) ? ((uint8 *)Memory)[i + j] : '.');
            }
            fprintf(fp, "\n");
        }
        fclose(fp);
        return true;
    }
    else
    {
        printf("UtMem2HexFile: Error Opening File: %s, %s\n", Filename, strerror(errno));
        UtAssert_True(false, "UtMem2HexFile: Error Opening File");
        return false;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtMem2HexFile:
typedef uint8_t   uint8
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
#define UtAssert_True(Expression, __VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(Expression,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other fragments need not be investigated for Rule 8.13 because they do not remove const qualification or create non-const pointers to memory that is passed as const. The function parameters are already declared with const where appropriate (const void *Memory, const char *Filename). Calls to fopen, fprintf, fclose, printf, strerror, and UtAssert_True do not perform casts that change const qualification. There are no other pointer casts or pointer assignments in the function aside from the listed fragments, and integer arithmetic/indexing operations do not affect pointer constness. Therefore only the listed lines (which perform casts from const-qualified Memory to a non-const uint8 * via (uint8 *)Memory) require investigation for compliance with Rule 8.13.
